title: Substitutes use immunity for transactional immunity
summary: Redefines an immunity recipient as a person who has been a witness in a legal proceeding and who has given evidence therein, and whose evidence (or any information directly or indirectly derived therefrom) may not be used against him in any criminal case; provides that a prosecutor may use evidence from a source independent of the defendant's immunized testimony against such immunity recipient; provides that, upon a motion by such immunity recipient to suppress such independent evidence, it shall be the burden of the prosecution to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, that such evidence was derived from an independent source.

BILL NUMBER:S1959

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the criminal procedure law, in relation to substituting use
immunity for transactional immunity

SUMMARY OF BILL:
This bill redefines an immunity recipient as a person who has been a
witness in a legal proceeding and who has given evidence therein, and
whose evidence (or any information directly or indirectly derived
therefrom) may not be used against him in any criminal case.

A prosecutor may use evidence from a source independent of the
defendant's immunized testimony. But, upon a motion by the defendant
to suppress the evidence, it is the burden of the prosecutor to
prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, that such evidence was derived from
an independent source.

Finally, the bill precludes, with few exceptions, a grand jury for
indicting a witness upon whom it has conferred immunity. The same
grand jury that conferred immunity can only subsequently indict the
witness for perjury or contempt or where the immunity was conferred
solely because the witness produced documents or other physical
evidence for which he possessed a privilege against
self-incrimination with respect to the act of producing the evidence.
A different grand jury panel can, however, subsequently indict the
witness for any offense based on evidence for which he does not have
immunity.

JUSTIFICATION:
The current New York Law governing immunity from prosecution is
illogical, capricious, inflexible and contrary to public interest.
The existing law confers total immunity and benefits no one except
the criminal. Furthermore, the criminal can take advantage of the
prosecutor's mistake or manipulation at testimony to achieve total
immunity for himself or herself. The current law also hinders
investigations by discouraging prosecutors from calling witnesses who
may themselves obtain a total immunity from any prosecution. There
are no constitutional, legal or practical reasons for allowing the
blanket immunity conferred by New York's law. Its results are
self-defeating, unjust, and not a reflection of the intentions of the
CPL drafters.

The transactional immunity provision is unrealistically restrictive.
It prevents the legitimate prosecution of many offenses, especially
those involving sophisticated or close-knit criminal groups.
Additionally, it has been construed by the courts to grant complete
transactional immunity in situations that the law cannot have
reasonably intended, and which are contrary to the public interest.
For example, in one case it was

held that a witness who testified before a grand jury investigating a
homicide received immunity from unrelated pending charges of specific
drug sales simply because she testified, as a general matter, that
she sold drugs for a living.
PEOPLE V. MCFARLAN, 42 NY 2d 896 (1977).

This bill changes the law from "transactional" immunity to "use"
immunity. It is derived from a federal statute, Title 18, U.S.C.
sections 6002 and 6003, which was approved by the united States
supreme Court in
KASTIGAR V. UNITED STATES, 405 U.S. 441 (1972).
The Court in KASTIGAR
held that a witness compelled to testify under a statutory scheme
like the one in this bill would receive all the benefits to which he
is entitled under the Fifth Amendment to the United States
constitution.
Under KASTIGAR, the purpose, except if his testimony
were perjurious
or contumacious. This means, as is stated explicitly in the bill,
that even information derived directly or indirectly from the
witness' testimony cannot be used against him or her.

This last provision places a heavy burden upon a prosecutor who
decides to proceed against a witness who has received immunity. Under

KASTIGAR, in such a case, the prosecution would have the
"affirmative duty to prove that the evidence it proposes to use is
derived from a legitimate source wholly independent of the compelled
testimony".
406 U.S. AT 460.
The Second Circuit Court of Appeals
has suggested
that the prosecution would be unlikely to meet such a burden unless
it somehow certified the evidence in its possession before it moved
to compel testimony.
GOLDBERG V. UNITED STATES, 472 F.2d 573,
516 n.5 (1973).
Under this bill, if the people wish to prosecute a person whose
testimony they also wish to compel, they must be prepared to prove
beyond a reasonable doubt that the evidence used against him was not
derived from his testimony.

To ensure that witnesses who are granted immunity are properly
protected against prejudice, the bill prohibits, with narrow
exceptions, a grand jury from indicting a witness upon whom it has
conferred immunity.
witnesses may be indicted by the grand jury that conferred immunity
only for the offenses of perjury or contempt or only where the
immunity was conferred for the act of producing books, papers,
records or other physical evidence. A different grand jury may,
however, indict the immunized witness for an offense based on other
evidence for which he does not have immunity.

This bill implements a recommendation contained in prior Annual
Messages to the Legislature by the Governor.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
The first day of November after it has become a law.
